div.l: How that the hopir waggis to and fro
Aleyn Answerd Iohn wilt thou soo
Þan wil I be beneþe l by my corne crovn̄cornecrovn̄
And se hou the mele falles a dovne
Into the trough · that shal be my disport
For Iohn in faith I may be one of yoᵘur sort
I is as ille a Milner͗e as yee
Þis mylner smyled at their͗e nycetee
And thought al this is don̄ but for a wile
They wene þᵗat no man̄ may them begile
But be my thrift yit shal I blere þeir͗e iye
For all their sleight and their͗e philosophy
Þe mo queynt crekis that they make
Þe more wil I stele whan̄ that I take
In stede of floure yit wil I yeve þem bren̄

l.hi: The gretist clerkis be not wisist men̄

div.l: As whilom the wulf spak to the mare
Of al their͗e art ne count I not a tare
¶Out of the dore he goth fulle pⁱriuely
Whan that he sawe his tyme softely
He lokid up and doun̄ til he had found
Þe clerkis hors where he stode y bound
Behynd the Mille vndir a lefeselle
And to the hors he goþ him feir͗e ⁊and well
He strepith of the bridil right anon̄
And whan̄ the hors was louse he gȳnneþ to gon̄
Toward the fenne ther wilde maris ryn̄
And furth with wehe thurgh thik ⁊and thyn̄
The mylner goth ageyn̄ no word he seyd
But doth his note and wᵗith these clerkꝭis pleid
Til that her corn̄ was feir͗e y grounde
And whan̄ the mele was sacked ⁊and y bound
Þis Iohn goth out and fynt his hors awey
And gan̄ to crye harrow and welaway
Oure hors is lost aleyn̄ for goddis benys
Steppe on̄ thy feet com̄ of man̄ Atteny
